text.text: Welcome to the watchOS Digital Lounge!

blocks.alt_text: A multi-colored outline of two gauges on a black background

text.text: Welcome to the WWDC22 watchOS Digital Lounge! We’ve got an exciting week planned for you. You can find the full schedule of events in the <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=yy47r7z7| Apple Developer app and on developer.apple.com>, and activities for all lounges kick off on June 7.
If you haven't already, please take a moment to familiarize yourself with <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=735utu4s|how the Digital Lounges will work>.

We want to make sure these spaces are helpful and welcoming for everyone — developers and Apple employees alike. Please review and follow the <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/policies/interactive-events/1/Apple-Developer-WWDC22-Interactive-Events-Attendance-Policy.pdf| WWDC22 Interactive Events Policy>.

messages.text: Hello and welcome! We’ll kick off our first watchOS digital lounge in about 13 minutes!

elements.text: Hello and welcome! We’ll kick off our first watchOS digital lounge in about 13 minutes!

messages.text: <@U03H96N55U5> added a workflow to this channel: *WatchOS - Ask a Question*.
<@U03H96N55U5> added a workflow to this channel: *WatchOS - Idea Submission*.

Welcome to Watch Development Q&A! We’re looking forward to answering your questions. Select the :heavy_plus_sign: icon from the lower left, and find the _Ask A Question_ workflow. Type in your question and it will be delivered directly to the team. We’ll answer as many questions as we can. While it’s unlikely we’ll be able to address every question, we’re excited to know what _you’re_ excited about, so ask away.

Let’s get started!

messages.text:
<@U03HMEM4TM5> asked
> How should we update our complications going forward? Are complication updates from iPhone still supported?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"How should we update our complications going forward? Are complication updates from iPhone still supported?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Nothing has changed with the ClockKit API in this release. Your app can request timeline reloads via `CLKComplicationServer.sharedInstance.reloadTimeline(for: ...)`

elements.text: Nothing has changed with the ClockKit API in this release. Your app can request timeline reloads via

slackdump_thread_replies.text: And a similar mechanism exists if you move to WidgetKit based complications

elements.text: And a similar mechanism exists if you move to WidgetKit based complications

slackdump_thread_replies.text: `WidgetCenter.shared.reloadTimelines(ofKind: ...)`

I see, thanks! So I assume the data flow is that it’s still up to the Watch app to react from `transferCurrentComplicationUserInfo` , store the data somehow, and trigger an update — in watchOS 9 or later using the WidgetKit API, in earlier watchOS versions using the CLK API, right?

elements.text: I see, thanks! So I assume the data flow is that it’s still up to the Watch app to react from
, store the data somehow, and trigger an update — in watchOS 9 or later using the WidgetKit API, in earlier watchOS versions using the CLK API, right?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If you want to simplify, you can call both and the system will only reload your widgets if you’re running on watchOS 9 or later and have adopted WidgetKit based complications.

elements.text: If you want to simplify, you can call both and the system will only reload your widgets if you’re running on watchOS 9 or later and have adopted WidgetKit based complications.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: After migrating to WidgetKit, your ClockKit based complications will no longer be run.

elements.text: After migrating to WidgetKit, your ClockKit based complications will no longer be run.

messages.text:
<@U03JELPN197> asked
> Do you have any tips to run a bigger App with support for Complications and Siri Intents on a real Apple Watch with the debugger? Currently I have to be lucky to get it to work.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Do you have any tips to run a bigger App with support for Complications and Siri Intents on a real Apple Watch with the debugger? Currently I have to be lucky to get it to work."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Here's a couple tips!

Like any wireless connection, the connection between Apple Watch and iPhone is dependent on network conditions.

When debugging, Apple Watch automatically prefers a WiFi connection to the phone to improve the speed. However, that has some requirements:
• The iPhone and Watch are on the same WiFi network.
• Consider that some Apple Watches only work on 2.4Ghz networks.
• Some networks disable peer to peer connections, which will prevent WiFi from working.
• Network congestion can play a part in causing issues.
• Make sure the Apple Watch is sufficiently charged (we recommend keeping the watch on the charging puck while debugging)
If WiFi is otherwise unavailable, we use Bluetooth for the connection which will be slower.

messages.text:
<@U03HMEM4TM5> asked
> What happens if a WidgetKit-backed complication update is running while I request another reload of the "widgets"? Is the second request dropped, or enqueued to the end of the current "reload"? Thanks!

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What happens if a WidgetKit-backed complication update is running while I request another reload of the \"widgets\"? Is the second request dropped, or enqueued to the end of the current \"reload\"? Thanks!"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The second is enqueued. If you add a third… we’ll take a peek at the requests and decide which one to keep

elements.text: The second is enqueued. If you add a third… we’ll take a peek at the requests and decide which one to keep

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is because a reload might be in-progress just as you get new data, and so your app requests another reload. It’d be mean for us to ignore that second one, since you had no control over when the first reload actually happens

elements.text: This is because a reload might be in-progress just as you get new data, and so your app requests another reload. It’d be mean for us to ignore that second one, since you had no control over when the first reload actually happens

slackdump_thread_replies.text: But if you give us a third reload request…, well that’s greedy and we will throw one away :)

elements.text: But if you give us a third reload request…, well that’s greedy and we will throw one away :)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: There was a cool WidgetKit talk in WWDC 2021 about reloads and budgets

elements.text: There was a cool WidgetKit talk in WWDC 2021 about reloads and budgets

slackdump_thread_replies.text: thanks! I mean, if the user makes 3 changes in the app, that does mean that we honestly need to update 3 times

elements.text: thanks! I mean, if the user makes 3 changes in the app, that does mean that we honestly need to update 3 times

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I suppose you’d recommend throttling?

There’s nothing wrong with requesting a third time, because you don’t control when the reloads will happen. We’ll be sure to keep one of the reload requests queued up, and when budgets allow, we’ll reload your widget with whatever is the current latest content

elements.text: There’s nothing wrong with requesting a third time, because you don’t control when the reloads will happen. We’ll be sure to keep one of the reload requests queued up, and when budgets allow, we’ll reload your widget with whatever is the current latest content

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We’ll do throttling too. Depends on several factors such as how frequently your widget is viewed, and there is a daily budget. <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/widgetkit/keeping-a-widget-up-to-date> has more

elements.text: We’ll do throttling too. Depends on several factors such as how frequently your widget is viewed, and there is a daily budget.

messages.text:
<@U03HVF46TEJ> asked
> Do the new WidgetKit complications support all existing Watch faces? Or do we still need to handle the older complication families separately using `CLKComplicationTemplateWhatever`?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Do the new WidgetKit complications support all existing Watch faces? Or do we still need to handle the older complication families separately using `CLKComplicationTemplateWhatever`?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: WidgetKit supports all watch faces that previously used the "graphic" complication templates. Luckily, we also updated a bunch of watch faces to use that "graphic" style in watchOS 9!

elements.text: WidgetKit supports all watch faces that previously used the "graphic" complication templates. Luckily, we also updated a bunch of watch faces to use that "graphic" style in watchOS 9!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Once you start using WidgetKit for complications, the system will always prefer using those complications even if your app provides complications via ClockKit.

elements.text: Once you start using WidgetKit for complications, the system will always prefer using those complications even if your app provides complications via ClockKit.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: There's some great sessions this year that goes over the migration path between ClockKit and WidgetKit.

elements.text: There's some great sessions this year that goes over the migration path between ClockKit and WidgetKit.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks! Is there a good list of which faces now use graphic complication? That's been a little tricky to piece together in the past.
All the faces in watchOS 9 support graphic complications.

elements.text: All the faces in watchOS 9 support graphic complications.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The talk on Thursday, Go further with Complications in WidgetKit, goes into more detail about this.

elements.text: The talk on Thursday, Go further with Complications in WidgetKit, goes into more detail about this.

messages.text:
<@U03JRQ9ADA4> asked
> Hello everyone! How can we schedule local notifications to be displayed on watchOS apps with a companion iOS app and a custom notification view? I mean, if a notification is scheduled on the iPhone, does this get shown on the Watch using our custom notification view - or do we have to provide additional configuration to "share" notifications across the two devices?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hello everyone! How can we schedule local notifications to be displayed on watchOS apps with a companion iOS app and a custom notification view? I mean, if a notification is scheduled on the iPhone, does this get shown on the Watch using our custom notification view - or do we have to provide additional configuration to \"share\" notifications across the two devices?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If you have a custom `WKNotificationScene` in your watch app, it will be used to display the notification that’s automatically forwarded to the watch by the system. (IOW, the system handles coordination between the watch and the phone.)

elements.text: in your watch app, it will be used to display the notification that’s automatically forwarded to the watch by the system. (IOW, the system handles coordination between the watch and the phone.)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: the local notification scheduled from your iPhone will automatically display on the watch when appropriate, you only need a `WKNotificationScene` if you want to customize the UI of the notification on the watch

elements.text: the local notification scheduled from your iPhone will automatically display on the watch when appropriate, you only need a
if you want to customize the UI of the notification on the watch

slackdump_thread_replies.text: No. The Watch app can instantiate a `CBCentralManager` and communicate with peripherals, but it cannot be a peripheral.

messages.text: Hi folks! We’re getting quite a few questions about using WatchConnectivity in the simulator, and rather than trying to tackle them one at a time, I wanted to provide a bit of general guidance: Namely, _testing networking on the simulator is not recommended. It’s best to use real devices._ :thread:

elements.text: Hi folks! We’re getting quite a few questions about using WatchConnectivity in the simulator, and rather than trying to tackle them one at a time, I wanted to provide a bit of general guidance: Namely,
testing networking on the simulator is not recommended. It’s best to use real devices.

Hey everyone. Welcome to “Build a Watch Productivity App” Watch Party! :watch:We’re all pumped to have you all here! My name is Paola and I’m a watchOS project manager. Make sure you get the video ready to go to hit play at 2:05 PDT.
While we wait, let me introduce you to the speaker: Anne! Along with Anne we have team members from watchOS development ready to answer your questions.
As the video plays I will create threads where everyone can ask questions or chat. Once the video finishes we will have time left over for Q&A; so get your questions ready!

<@U03J22AU6DQ> asked
> Howdy :face_with_cowboy_hat: First of all, many thanks for the marvellous updates this year and such a great sessions!
> 
> My question is regarding Portrait watch face. I've been playing around with different images and what pique my curiosity was the fact that the same image might be used with depth effect on the new iOS Lock Screen while not supporting Portrait on the watch.
> It is correct to assume that the reason is different screen dimensions and Depth Effect requires some padding around the subject to work?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Starting with watchOS 9, the Portraits face _does_ support photos from your entire photos library (not only those taken in Portrait mode), just like the new lock screen. However, I think you're right in your analysis of screen size/shape, padding around the subject, etc. In order for the depth effect to work, there needs to be the right amount of overlap between the foreground subject and the time and the variables you mentioned that are different between the phone and watch would affect that amount.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: hi Jan! When the original Apple Watch was released, it was pretty revolutionary—but not very powerful (at least compared to the current models!). Thus in watchOS 1, the code for third-party WatchKit apps ran on iPhone, as an extension to the companion iOS app, and drove the UI on the Apple Watch.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The code _had_ to be in two targets, because they went to different devices! And the WatchKit Extension target truly was an extension.

elements.text: to be in two targets, because they went to different devices! And the WatchKit Extension target truly was an extension.

<@U03J8GR73HT> asked
> If we go with the new app target for an independent Watch app which doesn't contain an iPhone app, will we be able to convert it to a iPhone app with an independent watch app?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"If we go with the new app target for an independent Watch app which doesn't contain an iPhone app, will we be able to convert it to a iPhone app with an independent watch app?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
This can be done!
1. Add the iOS App Target
2. On the General settings for the iOS App Target, add the Watch App to the Frameworks, Libraries, and Embedded Content list.
3. On the Build Settings, search for Bundle Identifier. Set the WatchKit Companion App Bundle Identifier to the Bundle Identifier of the Watch App.
4. Delete the iOS Stub target that was originally created when you created the Watch Only app.
5. Delete the iOS Stub from the Watch App scheme Build.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes, audio and navigation sessions also give you unmetered refreshes on watchOS! <@U03JV0V5WEP> asked
> In our application we've got a screen with recently played content which pulled from repositories/api client in iOS counterpart app. But when the iOS app is not running then Watch application will never load that screen. The data exchange works through `WatchConnectivity` and in documentation it says "Sending a message from a watchOS app wakes up its paired iOS app if it's reachable." But if we "kill" iOS application the messages will be never delivered (as far as we see the mentioned screen above doesn't loads). Is there any other way to wake it up? Maybe you have any advice how to debug it?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"In our application we've got a screen with recently played content which pulled from repositories\/api client in iOS counterpart app. But when the iOS app is not running then Watch application will never load that screen. The data exchange works through `WatchConnectivity` and in documentation it says \"Sending a message from a watchOS app wakes up its paired iOS app if it's reachable.\" But if we \"kill\" iOS application the messages will be never delivered (as far as we see the mentioned screen above doesn't loads). Is there any other way to wake it up? Maybe you have any advice how to debug it?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I’d suggest using the WatchConnectivity’s Application Context to communicate the information from iOS to Watch. The Application Context is intended to be there when the app launches and the values can be updated if something changes. For more information about the different parts of WatchConnectivity and when you might use each one (and other data communication technologies that might be useful), check out this session: <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10003/>.

This is certainly a reasonable analogy (and not even where something is fragile). The more you make your model testable and test that directly, the more efficient you can make your testing. You can also potentially keep your quality high (assuming your tests are well-designed, of course). :slightly_smiling_face:
UI tests will take longer to develop and run. Having good model tests allows you to focus your UI tests on testing the actual UI.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: From what you’re describing, you don’t need data transfer at all. Your _app_ can store the fact that you ate the donut (your intent could be invoked by something like, “hey Siri, tell MyDietTracker that I ate a donut,” and MyDietTracker records that you ate the donut. The complication can be updated based on that data when the app is running, or using background app refresh.

Hi, Simon.

I have verified that if you use `CMFallDetectionManager`  to observe fall events this does not affect the default system behavior. Your app will be briefly woken up in response to fall events so that it can do a small amount of work, like sending a notification, or something similar.

<@U03JJQ3BMB7> asked
> Testing SwiftUI on watchOS - is there documentation or a video you would recommend for getting started with this? Thank you!

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Testing SwiftUI on watchOS - is there documentation or a video you would recommend for getting started with this? Thank you!"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
The best way to test your SwiftUI app on watchOS is to make your model layer testable and write thorough tests for that with XCTest. This will allow you to concentrate you UI testing on Watch to the UI itself.
You can build a test suite for your model layer and run it to catch any regressions. You can find documentation for XCTest here: <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xctest>, and there are a lot of great WWDC session videos about designing and writing tests.

, and there are a lot of great WWDC session videos about designing and writing tests.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi, Emre. There are a couple of parts to this question, but I think the most important part is whether it's better to do a large amount of work spread out over a longer period of time or to do it all at once.

There are a couple of great WWDC talks that address this. One that really helped me to get into the right mindset about this was this one: <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2015/707/>

Doing a task on a mobile device requires spinning up whatever hardware is needed to do the task. That can be a CPU, or wireless radios. All of those things require power to run, and turning them on and off frequently is a very quick way to burn down the user's battery. So the best thing to do is to do as much work as you can in as short a time as possible and then let the device go back to sleep.

attachments.fallback:
[June 7th, 2022 1:47 PM] -8472326468381093966: Here's a couple tips!

Like any wireless connection, the connection between Apple Watch and iPhone is dependent on network conditions.

When debugging, Apple Watch automatically prefers a WiFi connection to the phone to improve the speed. However, that has some requirements:
• The iPhone and Watch are on the same WiFi network.
• Consider that some Apple Watches only work on 2.4Ghz networks.
• Some networks disable peer to peer connections, which will prevent WiFi from working.
• Network congestion can play a part in causing issues.
• Make sure the Apple Watch is sufficiently charged (we recommend keeping the watch on the charging puck while debugging)
If WiFi is otherwise unavailable, we use Bluetooth for the connection which will be slower.
attachments.text:
Here's a couple tips!

Like any wireless connection, the connection between Apple Watch and iPhone is dependent on network conditions.

When debugging, Apple Watch automatically prefers a WiFi connection to the phone to improve the speed. However, that has some requirements:
• The iPhone and Watch are on the same WiFi network.
• Consider that some Apple Watches only work on 2.4Ghz networks.
• Some networks disable peer to peer connections, which will prevent WiFi from working.
• Network congestion can play a part in causing issues.
• Make sure the Apple Watch is sufficiently charged (we recommend keeping the watch on the charging puck while debugging)
If WiFi is otherwise unavailable, we use Bluetooth for the connection which will be slower.

<@U03J5EP5RSB> asked
> What's the best way to wake up iOS app from Watch app to keep it running? My iOS app is connecting to a server by socket and keep sending real time data to the Watch app. Is sending short messages to iPhone with an interval good way? Thank you

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What's the best way to wake up iOS app from Watch app to keep it running? My iOS app is connecting to a server by socket and keep sending real time data to the Watch app. Is sending short messages to iPhone with an interval good way? Thank you"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi, Emre.

Sending a message via WatchConnectivity from your Watch App will wake the iOS app. However, you can't due this forever, as the messaging will be limited eventually.

Can you tell us a bit more about what you're trying to do here?

elements.text:

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The other thing to know is that `NSUbiquitousKeyValueStore` is newly available in watchOS 9, and that’s a great option for storing preferences & configuration options across devices. Put passwords and OAuth tokens in the keychain, and use UKVS for the prefs. <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/foundation/nsubiquitouskeyvaluestore>

messages.text: Thank you so much for joining us in the Watch Development Digital Lounge! We hope you enjoyed interacting as we did! :smiling_face_with_3_hearts: Before you head out: *<https://essentials.applesurveys.com/jfe/form/SV_2cw6N3JbrxFcoiq|Our WWDC22 Developer Survey is now live>*! It would help us tremendously if you could take 5 minutes to let us know what you loved about WWDC22 and what we could make better for you. Your feedback has major impact on the programs and events we host for developers, and we’re excited to hear from you.

attachments.title: Apple
attachments.text: Thanks for joining us this year. WWDC is designed for you and your feedback is important to us. Providing responses to this survey is voluntary. It should take 5 minutes or less of your time. Do not include any information that may identify you in the text boxes. Your responses will not be tied to you and will be aggregated with other responses.

messages.text: We’re going to open threads up again for a few hours so you (and we) can follow up on some of the conversations we started earlier, and I’ll probably post a few more tips on issues that came up in our lab conversations. I’ll say it again: Hearing what y’all are working on and how you’re using (or want to use) the features and APIs we build is the highlight of our year. We love talking with you! Thanks again for a great WWDC. :blush:

messages.text: We say this a lot, but please do file Feedback. It doesn't go into a black hole; it tells us—especially when you describe your use case!—what’s important to you, and we consider it when making plans & prioritizing what to focus on. Duplicates are not a rejection or dismissal! They're effectively votes.
